definition:
A search problem $R$ is $\mathcal{C}$ self-reducible if there is a
$\mathcal{C}$ Cook reduction of $R$ to $L(R)$. That is, if the decision
problem for $L(R)$ is $\mathcal{C}$ then so is the search problem for
$R$.

If $R$ is polynomially self-reducible then it is called self-reducible.

Note that $L(R)$ is trivially Cook reducible to $R$.
